[SYNTAX]: Overly complex, winding sentence structures (e.g., first paragraph) may impede smooth reading.
[LEXICON]: Archaisms (e.g., "bewigged and powdered year") and poetic flourishes occasionally disrupt modern readability.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between Grasse’s local scene and Parisian political/artistic context (e.g., Pompadour narrative).
[STRUCTURE]: Repetitive contrasts between provincial tranquility and royal intrigue without clear narrative bridges.

[LEXICON]: Use of archaic vocabulary (e.g., "’twas", "dandified", "Rabelaisian wag") may impede readability for modern readers.
[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, complex sentence structures (e.g., multiple nested clauses).

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt insertion of historical event (Damiens stabbing the king) with unclear narrative connection to Fragonard’s story.
[TRANSITION]: Mild disjointedness between artistic development themes and biographical milestones.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally dense, complex sentence structures (e.g., "Meantime, Choiseul’s masterly mind...") may interrupt smooth readability.
[LEXICON]: Archaic or overly formal phrasing (e.g., "the light one," "reborn under a forged birth-certificate").

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between Fragonard’s artistic career, historical/political events (e.g., Jesuit abolition, Madame du Barry’s introduction), and biographical asides.
[STRUCTURE]: Subsections (e.g., Pompadour’s death, Guimard’s conflict) feel loosely connected to the broader narrative arc.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, poetic sentence structures (e.g., "the massy foliage and the majestic trees that spring into the swinging heavens") may slightly slow readability.
[LEXICON]: Rare archaic/vivid terms ("light-o'-love," "massy foliage") could marginally distract modern readers.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from Du Barry’s rejection of Fragonard’s work to his marriage and artistic evolution (e.g., "The fact was that the Du Barry was of the gutter..." to "There lived in Grasse...").
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential details (e.g., Du Barry’s bills, Dutch influence) feel loosely integrated into the narrative flow.

[COMPLEXITY]: Overly elaborate sentence structures with multiple embedded clauses (e.g., "Choiseul was too astute a man not to recognise what lay beyond the shadow of her pretty skirts--nay, does he not turn in the courtyard...").
[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary/phrasing (e.g., "Ay," "methinks," "whilst") that may impede modern readability.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transitions between historical events (e.g., Boucher’s death → political intrigue → Fragonard’s journey) without clear thematic or temporal bridges.
[LOGIC]: Assumed historical context (e.g., significance of "Pacte de Famille," "lettre de cachet") with insufficient explanation for standalone clarity.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex, lengthy sentences may slightly impede smooth flow (e.g., "the vile accent of Grasse...").
[LEXICON]: Minor archaic phrasing ("saw the dawn of the Revolution," "tragic red") but remains clear.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shifts between Fragonard’s personal life and broad historical events (e.g., transition from family dynamics to Louis XVI’s reign).

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between Fragonard’s personal narrative and broader historical events (e.g., Robespierre’s fall, Napoleon’s rise) without clear connectors.
